{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2966748,"name":"Jeffrey Burt","username":"Drogo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/drogo/{size}/225639_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-28T23:08:06.165Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone,

I’m working on a project that requires precise control and prediction of motor torque, and I’ve run into a slight theoretical problem. Well falcons have detailed specs for torqueing in the forward direction (torqueing in the direction of rotor travel/speeding up the rotor), there are no published specs for torqueing in reverse (torqueing against the direction of rotor travel/slowing down the rotor).

Now if my knowledge of BLDC physics is correct, the back EMF present in the motor will allow the motor to go beyond its rated stall torque when the motor is torqueing in reverse. I believe this torque at a given speed will be equal to: stall torque + (stall torque - max forward at current motor speed) or (2 * stall torque) - max forward at current motor speed.

So my question is 1: is my above physics/math correct, and 2: is it even safe to run the falcon above its rated stall torque? I can easily see how going above stall torque for anything but a quick burst could burn out the motor, so I’m wondering whether practically just limit myself to the motor’s stall torque.

Thanks for any help you give!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2021-08-28T23:08:06.165Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":297,"reads":232,"readers_count":231,"score":1531.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395770,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-maximum-torque","display_username":"Jeffrey Burt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":45866,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-maximum-torque/395770/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2966751,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-28T23:30:43.641Z","cooked":"

This is correct. If you draw a motor in schematic, you’ll see that when reversing direction, back-emf works “in your favor” effectively doubling the voltage across the coils, and, sans inductance effects, you’ll get double the current. Note that inductance will mess with this conclusion a bit as the current will take time to fall, during which the motor will decelerate, but it’s a phenomenon best modeled in LTSpice or a similar software to see what happens for a particular motor.

Finding inductance for a motor can be tricky, and for a BLDC motor the assumptions might start to break down. @solomondg would probably know more.

In Layman’s terms, does this mean a BLDC motor can decelerate at twice the rate it can accelerate (friction and gravity aside) ?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2021-08-29T00:41:35.847Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":197,"readers_count":196,"score":49.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395770,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-maximum-torque","display_username":"Jesse Knight","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":21715,"username":"asid61","name":"Anand Rajamani","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-maximum-torque/395770/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2966758,"name":"Josh Nichols","username":"JN25","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/87869e/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-08-29T01:28:03.899Z","cooked":"

Pretty much…

This can be explained by a variant of the common characterization equation: Voltage = kt * torque + kv * velocity. It’s then pretty clear that maximum torque ocurrs when the motor is running at its minimum free velocity, and that minimum torque ocurrs when the robot is running at its maximum free velocity, both of which are twice that possible at a velocity of zero (ignoring friction/gravity/other natural disturbances of course). An interesting result is that when motor dynamics are accounted for, trapezoidal motion profiles are no longer time-optimal,

“Minimum Free Velocity” is not clear. Is that at min applied or max applied voltage?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2021-08-29T01:56:24.737Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":62.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395770,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-maximum-torque","display_username":"Jesse Knight","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49398,"username":"JN25","name":"Josh Nichols","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/87869e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-maximum-torque/395770/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2966764,"name":"Josh Nichols","username":"JN25","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/87869e/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-08-29T02:00:25.030Z","cooked":"

Minimum free velocity is the speed the motor stabilizes to when the minimum voltage is applied (-12 volts for example) and maximum free velocity is the speed the motor stabilizes to when the maximum voltage is applied (12 volts for example).
